key_points: COVID-19 vaccines developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna require two doses for full efficacy.
The Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine only requires one dose.
The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines use mRNA technology to trigger an immune response against the coronavirus.
Full immunity from the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines typically takes around 2 weeks after the second dose.
The second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is administered 3 weeks after the first, and Moderna's second dose comes 4 weeks after the first.
The CDC allows the second dose to be administered up to 4 days earlier than recommended, or up to 6 weeks (42 days) after the first dose in certain situations.
Initial immunity is observed after the first dose of both Pfizer-BioNTech (52-91% effective) and Moderna (50.8-92.1% effective) vaccines.
After the second dose, vaccine effectiveness is 95% for Pfizer-BioNTech and 94.1% for Moderna.
Discussions about delaying or eliminating the second dose to increase vaccine coverage have raised concerns about long-term immunity and variant emergence.
The CDC does not recommend mixing Pfizer and Moderna vaccines; the same product should be used for both doses.
